000d10e6d03eeb8a50a6feed67578cbe (02:28): du -sk / shows file size of all partitions.. how do just check all dir size that are only part of '/' partition?
b4e23593ef02e114f30b5b85761fe1e4 (02:30): it's in the man page
000d10e6d03eeb8a50a6feed67578cbe (02:32): du: invalid option -- d
000d10e6d03eeb8a50a6feed67578cbe (02:32): elektronkind: is is gnu du ?
b4e23593ef02e114f30b5b85761fe1e4 (02:32): sorry, I was looking at gnu du
b4e23593ef02e114f30b5b85761fe1e4 (02:32): I was looking at sunos du
000d10e6d03eeb8a50a6feed67578cbe (02:32): elektronkind: no u r right.. i was looking at gnu du
b4e23593ef02e114f30b5b85761fe1e4 (02:32): you must be using gnu du
000d10e6d03eeb8a50a6feed67578cbe (02:33): elektronkind: hehe
000d10e6d03eeb8a50a6feed67578cbe (02:33): elektronkind: it gives the total size.. i wanted to see all the dir size wihtin '/'
10e088c2e6de1fbb42befa8f10718a73 (02:34): axisys:  du -sk --max-depth 1 /
10e088c2e6de1fbb42befa8f10718a73 (02:34): should work at least with gnu du
d29f7858616789349f2e17f17eaa3395 (02:36): I just tried -hs on snv46 and on openbsd, so it should work with sun du and bsd du...
316982397a0e69355664adb9941f9144 (02:36): elektronkind: at the moment, prince george
316982397a0e69355664adb9941f9144 (02:37): in ~ 2 years (when i'm done this degree) back to vancouver
316982397a0e69355664adb9941f9144 (02:39): "geography, all right!"
000d10e6d03eeb8a50a6feed67578cbe (02:40): -s cant be used with --max-depth
10e088c2e6de1fbb42befa8f10718a73 (02:40): axisys: drop -s ;)
000d10e6d03eeb8a50a6feed67578cbe (02:40): du -hs included /tmp which is separate dir.. i checked
000d10e6d03eeb8a50a6feed67578cbe (02:40): cnuke: then it shows every signle file even in subdir
10e088c2e6de1fbb42befa8f10718a73 (02:41): axisys: du -h --max-depth 1 / works fine with gnu du
10e088c2e6de1fbb42befa8f10718a73 (02:41): and so on...
000d10e6d03eeb8a50a6feed67578cbe (02:42): cnuke: that is the one.. -k did not work.. excellent
000d10e6d03eeb8a50a6feed67578cbe (02:43): cnuke: take it back du -h --max-depth 1 / did not work it adds /var which is separate partition
10e088c2e6de1fbb42befa8f10718a73 (02:44): axisys: of course. du checks all dirs on /. it doesn't care about different partitons
000d10e6d03eeb8a50a6feed67578cbe (02:45): how do i check all dir and file size within '/' partition not subdir and not dir outside '/' partition
10e088c2e6de1fbb42befa8f10718a73 (02:45): twincest: i guess he is using gnu du which doesn't have this option
aac6faa59982955179bb909138afd162 (02:45): why's he using gnu du?
000d10e6d03eeb8a50a6feed67578cbe (02:45): i could use either .. whichever works
aac6faa59982955179bb909138afd162 (02:46): gnu du has -x
000d10e6d03eeb8a50a6feed67578cbe (02:46): du -d shows all file size recursively
aac6faa59982955179bb909138afd162 (02:47): axi: that's what du does.  specify other options if you want it to behave differently
000d10e6d03eeb8a50a6feed67578cbe (02:48): well du -sk /usr works fine.. but du -sk / does not because it include /usr which is seperate partition
10e088c2e6de1fbb42befa8f10718a73 (02:48): twincest: iirc -x will also list the dir but doesn't count the content
000d10e6d03eeb8a50a6feed67578cbe (02:49): du -skd / gives only the total size of / .. i want same output as du -sk /usr gives for /usr partition
aac6faa59982955179bb909138afd162 (02:49): cnuke: that seems like correct behaviour, since the directory must exist on the parent filesystem.  does du -d work differently?
aac6faa59982955179bb909138afd162 (02:49): axi: what does du -sk /usr give, if not the total size of /usr?
10e088c2e6de1fbb42befa8f10718a73 (02:49): twincest: not at all :)
000d10e6d03eeb8a50a6feed67578cbe (02:50): cd /usr; du -sk * .. u get size of all the folders and file on top dir
aac6faa59982955179bb909138afd162 (02:50): yes, but that's not the same as du -sk /usr... what are you trying to do?
6c728b2ae6e0bdb14ac212ed5f74c1d8 (02:50): umpf... the danise copper vs. j??rg schilling vs. debian vs. world vs. universe vs. metaverse vs. mugiha hit wikipedia hart... ;-(
6c728b2ae6e0bdb14ac212ed5f74c1d8 (02:51): http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CDDL
000d10e6d03eeb8a50a6feed67578cbe (02:51): du -skd /* includes /usr which is a separate partition
000d10e6d03eeb8a50a6feed67578cbe (02:52): is there a way i can tell it not to go outside its partition? may be a different switch or tool?!
10e088c2e6de1fbb42befa8f10718a73 (02:52): axisys: if you know which dirs are on a sperate part, why do you not exclude these dirs?
000d10e6d03eeb8a50a6feed67578cbe (02:52): cnuke: that is one way :-)
10e088c2e6de1fbb42befa8f10718a73 (02:53): imho the easiest
000d10e6d03eeb8a50a6feed67578cbe (02:53): cnuke: i guess so .. hehe

6c728b2ae6e0bdb14ac212ed5f74c1d8 (02:59): g4lt-U60: well, that was a countermeasurement against possible cddl-is-evil-all-cddl-licensed-projects-must-DIEDIEDIEDIEDIEDIE-debian-megatrolls
8c27c6238210e78d0cff9690db08116b (03:00): ahh, and it'd be rather ironic on many levels if I was the hammer too
aac6faa59982955179bb909138afd162 (03:02): axi: for file in *; do if ! [ "`[ ! -f $file ] && ls -id $file/. | awk '{print $1}'`" = 2 ]; then du -sk $file; fi; done
aac6faa59982955179bb909138afd162 (03:05): not sure how well that'll work for ZFS or other non-UFS stuff
8c27c6238210e78d0cff9690db08116b (03:10): aren't all of those commaands FS agnostic?
